title: Case Study: Boutonniere Deformity of the Ring Finger in an Elderly Gardener
clinical_history: Mr. Walter Hughes is a 68-year-old retired school principal and avid gardener who presents with a 3-week history of deformity and swelling of his right ring finger following a minor laceration sustained while pruning rose bushes. He initially managed the wound at home. Within days, Walter noticed increasing swelling and difficulty extending the middle joint (PIP) of his finger while the tip (DIP) became hyperextended. He reports pain and stiffness, especially when grasping tools or making a fist. On examination, there is evident flexion at the PIP and hyperextension at the DIP of the right ring finger, with tenderness and swelling localized to the PIP region. He denies numbness or tingling in the hand. Functionally, he struggles to grip objects, limiting his gardening activities significantly.

nprs.affected_area: PIP joint of right ring finger (localised at central slip insertion/lateral bands)
Dorsum of right hand (secondary discomfort due to compensatory hand use)

aggrevating_factors: Flexing the affected finger, grasping objects, holding gardening tools, typing for extended periods, cold weather exacerbates stiffness.
picture: [insert image showing classic boutonniere deformity with PIP flexion and DIP hyperextension of the ring finger]
easing_factors: Resting the hand, gentle passive extension exercises, warm water soaks, topical NSAID gel applications.
past_history: No previous hand trauma. He reports well-controlled Type II diabetes for 15 years, which occasionally delays wound healing.
medical_history: Type II diabetes mellitus (diagnosed 15 years ago), hypertension; both managed with medications. No known allergies.
medications: Metformin 1000mg BID, Lisinopril 10mg daily, topical Diclofenac gel for finger pain as needed.

imaging: Plain radiograph of right hand rules out fracture; no evidence of bone involvement, confirms soft tissue injury at the PIP. No subluxation of the PIP joint.
